comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: Am I right in assuming this is Farrar Place looking towards the intersection of Bligh and Bent Streets?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] i can't pick this street - HELP! www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]  I'm looking at the NSW Government Printer's map of Sydney dated 1900 and have now worked it out!  I think we're looking up Young Street towards the corner of Bent Street and Bligh Street. The Metropole lay at the intersection of Bent, Young and Philip Streets. The big building in Bligh Street is the Union Club.

On your map, Young Street is shown as "Elizabeth Street North" ... now the key  question ... when was the name changed?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Ah, thank you - that makes more sense - it looks so different without the Education Department Building on the right, but the terrace houses on the left should be there behind all the flags and bunting . Google street view (unrecognisable) - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] Don't you ever wish you lived back then? Just joking of course, but I preferred the 1901 street-scape!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Another superb effort, thank you! I'll update the caption to "Young Street, looking towards the corner of Bent and Bligh Streets".

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] I think I would prefer a little earlier, maybe 1860-1880, before the late Victorian overblown and heavy architecture, caused by the use of iron frame skeletons and the invention of the lift / elevator (thanks Mr Otis!).   Cities were on a much more human scale when buildings were limited to three or four stories, and steeples and towers were wonderful visions and markers on the horizon.  But the lack of services and sanitation, the pollution and smog from all those coal fires, and the smell of horse poo and wee in the streets would have been dreadful!  I keep meaning to tag all the old photos on Flickr with visible horse poo, for a laugh and to prove that the good ol' days weren't all good.
